Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dry in the sky? Ecophysiological Strategies and Drought Tolerance among Tropical Montane Cloud Forest Canopy Epiphytes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Epiphytes, plants that live on other plants, reach their peak of diversity and abundance in Tropical Montane Cloud Forests (TMCF). In this ecosystem, epiphytes play important ecosystem roles because they intercept and hold on to nutrients and water from rain and mist and provide food and resources for many birds, animals and insects. Because these plants do not have access to soils and water from the ground, they are particularly vulnerable to changes in climate, including increases in cloud height and drought. This research will determine the degree to which epiphyte communities are vulnerable to decreases in precipitation or cloud cover, and increased forest fragmentation. This project will also develop a training program in canopy ecology for ecotourism operators in Monteverde, Costa Rica. This region hosts over 100,000 people per year for canopy adventure sports but few tourists or guides get information on the importance of the TMCF in general and the epiphyte community specifically. The team will also provide training and presentations to local research and educational institutions in the Monteverde region including the Monteverde Reserve, the Monteverde Institute and local high schools.

Despite evidence that the canopy community as a whole is important to ecosystem processes, there is little information regarding the ability of this community to withstand projected changes in climate and/or increases in exposure due to deforestation. In the TMCF, there is great variation in growth forms in the canopy that may differ in their vulnerability to decreases in precipitation or increases in cloud base heights. Although efforts have been made to understand individual species responses to drought stress, little is known about variability in drought-stress responses and the ability of plants to cope with projected future drought conditions. By working in this hyper-diverse, but relatively understudied system, this research will increase the understanding of a fundamental topic in plant ecophysiology: the diverse ways plants respond to drought. Variability in microclimate across the six sites provides a unique opportunity to identify suites of drought-stress responses across functional groups and determine whether these traits vary, or respond plastically, to changes in the environment. Functional morphological traits, water relations, water use, and vulnerability to drought will be measured across the gradient to document variation in ecophysiological strategies in plants that are exposed to different microclimates. Photosynthetic strategies will also be evaluated along the gradient using stable isotopes. Canopy communities in open pasture trees will also be studied because these exposed communities tend to experience greater water stress within a given precipitation regime and may provide insights on how canopy communities are likely to be affected by increases in drought stress or forest fragmentation. To assess the role of suites of functional traits on drought resistance, a subset of common species from three of the sites (wettest, intermediate, driest) from both forests and pastures will be subjected to a manipulative drought experiment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2016, a collaborative team of scientists who study plants that live in the canopy of tropical forests (called epiphytes) began to research how these plants and the forests they live in respond to changes in climate and land use. They set up several study sites in Monteverde, Costa Rica, located in areas that ranged from high to low elevation , and in a range of land use types, including undisturbed forests and pastures. They used a combination of research approaches, including field observations, collection of plant species, manipulative experiments in the field and in greenhouses, and laboratory measurements. Their three goals were to: 1) document the effects of increasing temperature and drought on how these plants use water and carry out photosynthesis; 2) quantify differences in the abundance and plant diversity of canopy-dwelling plants among sites; and 3) determine the vulnerability of different forms of growth of canopy plants subjected to increasing levels of drought.

The project was successful in addressing each goal. The team learned that the rate of evaporation from the plant leaves into the surrounding atmosphere is particularly important for influencing the overall abundance of canopy plants, the richness of the species observed, and the plant’s water relations. They found large differences in “functional groups” (plant group share the ways they carry out carbon fixation and nutrient use) within and between across the sites. Species that were more succulent used water more conservatively than less succulent species, but non-succulent plants were better at taking up water through their leaves.  The team received a Grant Supplement to learn new measurement techniques to assess water stress.

Canopy plant community composition at the plant family level differed significantly between sites at higher versus lower elevation, and between pastures and forests.  Greenhouse experiments revealed that most canopy plants suffered under mild drought, but surprisingly, most species were able to recover quickly to re-watering. However, exposure to prolonged (severe) drought resulted in significant shifts in structural traits. in the lower elevation greenhouse, but not in the cloud forest greenhouse, which mimicked more natural field conditions.

In most past studies that model water movement and climate change impacts in the landscape, trees are the only plants considered. This work has extended those studies by including canopy epiphytic plants. These outcomes also benefit the conservation and restoration of epiphyte communities because understanding the relative vulnerability of different functional groups of canopy plants can help restoration workers to quantify losses of ecosystem services (e.g., resources for birds, retention of cloud waters)

Team members who received training in field and laboratory aspects of the project included one post-doctoral associate, three graduate students, one research associate, and 13 undergraduate students, nearly all of whom were included as co-authors on peer-reviewed papers. These students are now more familiar with the scientific process, have developed technical skills, and some have gone on to graduate programs in plant biology.  None of the students had significant international experience prior to working at the field location in Costa Rica, so the project also provided cultural and language experiences.

The team was committed to increasing diversity in STEM fields and in environmental biology[. Two graduate students on this project were women and one is Mexican American. Of the undergraduates, ten were women and four were people of color. This work provided research exposure to the local community via a 5-day field course and four bilingual public lectures.

The PIs and post-doc have given over 30 public lectures in the U.S. and Costa Rica to disseminate the results of this research project. These talks have also highlighted the effects that climate change are likely to have on tropical montane cloud forests and how those changes will impact ecosystem function. This research was featured in a French Television Docuseries (Terres Extremes), which played throughout Europe in 2019 and aired throughout Central America in 2020. One graduate student explored pathways of public engagement through a survey of visitors to local canopy zipline companies, and found that adventure tourism venues are amenable to disseminating scientific information about canopy biology. The research associate created a printed guide to canopy plants (60+ species).

The project faced challenges in coordinating communication from a remote site with unreliable internet access; transportation of equipment across international borders, and rigorous field conditions. However, the project has led their team to explore new areas of research in the future specifically the effects of loss of canopy plants on tree health, which may contribute to understanding how to mitigate the negative results of changes in climate land use in tropical cloud forests.
